metadata.title: Named Entity Recognition (NER) with BERT in Spark NLP | by Veysel Kocaman | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Named Entity Recognition (NER) with BERT in Spark NLP
metadata.description: NER is a subtask of information extraction that seeks to locate and classify named entities mentioned in unstructured text into pre-defined categories such as person names, organizations, locations…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Chiu & Nicols, Named Entity Recognition with Bidirectional LSTM-CNN
NER with Bert in Spark NLP notebook
How to train a NER model in Spark NLP with other word embeddings (Colab)
Installing Spark NLP and Spark OCR in air-gapped networks (offline mode)
Introduction to Spark NLP: Foundations and Basic Components (Part-I)
Introduction to: Spark NLP: Installation and Getting Started (Part-II)

all_paragraphs: NER is a subtask of information extraction that seeks to locate and classify named entities mentioned in unstructured text into pre-defined categories such as person names, organizations, locations, medical codes, time expressions, quantities, monetary values, percentages, etc.
NER is used in many fields in Natural Language Processing (NLP), and it can help to answer many real-world questions, such as:
NER is a lively topic in NLP and the research efforts are evolved through the years. We can summarize these efforts in the following topics:

In this article, we will try to show you how to build a state-of-the-art NER model with BERT in the Spark NLP library. The model we are going to implement is inspired by a former state of the art model for NER: Chiu & Nicols, Named Entity Recognition with Bidirectional LSTM-CNN and it is already embedded in Spark NLP NerDL Annotator. This is a novel neural network architecture that automatically detects word- and character-level features using a hybrid bidirectional LSTM and CNN architecture, eliminating the need for most feature engineering.
At the time of development of this model, there were no BERT-like language models and Glove word embeddings are being used in the original paper. But in this article, we will replace Glove with BERT.
In Spark NLP, there are three different pre-trained word embeddings models (and their variations) that you can plug and play depending on your use case.

For the sake of simplicity and save you some time, we will skip the installation steps. We already have another article focusing on Spark NLP in detail. And we will do all the work in Colab to let you jump into Spark NLP directly.
We start by downloading the train and test set. We will use the official CoNLL2003 dataset, a benchmark dataset that has been used in nearly all the NER papers. You can download this dataset here.

Let us briefly explain what CoNLL is. Abbreviation for ‘Conference on Natural Language Learning’, CoNLL is also the standard format for the annotations used in train sets to train NER models. Here is how it looks. You can annotate your own data in CONLL and then train a custom NER in Spark NLP. There are also some free annotation tools that you can use to label your own data.
Here is the flow that we are going to explain one by one.
We import the relevant packages and then start coding.
If you want to train your model on GPU, you can just start your Spark session with spark = sparknlp(gpu=True).
Then we convert the CoNLL file to Spark data frame with all the additional fields generated to be used later on.

As you see, the input dataset has only lines and labels, now we have several columns here. The CoNLL helper class we have in Spark NLP takes the dataset as input and prepares the tokens, POS (part-of-speech) and sentences that would be required by the NER algorithm we are going to use. All you need to do is to prepare or download a dataset in CoNLL format.

(Note: Even though the original paper suggests using the POS, it will not be used while training in Spark NLP. Since POS tags are in CONLL format, CoNLL helper class extracts them from CoNLL file given as an input. So, we can even have -X- instead of POS tags in that source CoNLL file.)
The next step is to get the word embeddings through BERT. We will use Spark NLP annotator called BertEmbeddings().

In Spark NLP, we have four pre-trained variants of BERT: bert_base_uncased , bert_base_cased , bert_large_uncased , bert_large_cased . Which one to use depends on your use case, train set, and the complexity of the task you are trying to model.

In the code snippet above, we basically load the bert_base_cased version from Spark NLP public resources and point thesentenceand token columns in setInputCols(). In short, BertEmbeddings() annotator will take sentenceand token columns and populate Bert embeddings in bert column. In general, each word is translated to a 768-dimensional vector. The parametersetPoolingLayer() can be set to 0 as the first layer and fastest, -1 as the last layer and -2 as the second-to-last-hidden layer.

As explained by the authors of official BERT paper, different BERT layers capture different information. The last layer is too closed to the target functions (i.e. masked language model and next sentence prediction) during pre-training, therefore it may be biased to those targets. If you want to use the last hidden layer anyway, please feel free to set pooling_layer=-1. Intuitively, pooling_layer=-1 is close to the training output, so it may be biased to the training targets. If you don't fine-tune the model, then this could lead to a bad representation. That said, it is a matter of trade-off between model accuracy and computational resources you have.
Then we import the NerDLApproach() annotator, the main module that is responsible for training the NER model.
.setInputCols([“sentence”, “token”, “bert”]) : the columns that will be used by NER model to generate features.
.setOutputCol(“ner”) : the predictions will be written to ner column
.setMaxEpochs(1) : number of epoch for training
.setVerbose(1) : the level of logs while training
.setValidationSplit(0.2) : the proportion of training dataset to be validated against the model on each Epoch. The value should be between 0.0 and 1.0 and by default, it is 0.0 and off.
.setEvaluationLogExtended(True) : Whether logs for validation to be extended: it displays time and evaluation of each label. The default is false.
.setEnableOutputLogs(True) : Whether to output to the log folder. When set True, the logs and training metrics will be written to folder in the home folder.
.setIncludeConfidence(True) : whether to include confidence scores in annotation metadata.

.setTestDataset(“test_withEmbeds.parquet”) : The path to test dataset. If set, it is used to calculate statistics on it during training. This is also in a CoNLL format but embeddings added through and saved to disk as before. You don’t have to set this if you don’t need to evaluate your model on an unseen test set in Spark.
You can also set learning rate ( setLr ), learning rate decay coefficient ( setPo ), setBatchSize and setDropout rate. Please see the official repo for the entire list.
Now we can append these two annotators in a pipeline.

When the fitting is finished depending on the dataset size and the number of epochs you set, it will be ready to be used. Let’s see how the logs look like after just 1 epoch (inside annotators_log folder in your home folder).
You can find this folder in the root directory of Colab instance.
In sum, we can train a custom NER in the SOTA algorithm with just a few lines of codes in Spark NLP.
We can also save this fitted NER model to the disk. Since NERDL model is the second stage in the pipeline (the first one is BertEmbedding annotator), we can refer to that by indexing in the stages.
and then load back later on using NerDLModel annotator.
and use in another pipeline (i.e. prediction pipeline)
fit the pipeline and get predictions.
We can also write some PySpark functions to make the output a little bit prettier and useful with the help of ner_span coming out of NerConverter.

We can also convert this pipeline to LightPipeline to get rid of the Spark overhead and have a lightning speed inference. Once you convert any fitted pipeline to LightPipeline, you can easily get predictions for strings or a list of strings way faster. You can find more detail about LightPipelines here.

All the code is available at Github. In the notebook we shared via Github, you will even see additional implementations with various other embedding and how to prepare your own CoNLL file to train custom NER models.
That’s all for now. In this article, we talked about how you can train a state-of-the-art NER model in Spark NLP with BERT, the coolest kid in NLP town. I hope you enjoyed!
We also held a webinar about this topic and the recording is available here!

We hope that you already read the previous articles on our official Medium page, and started to play with Spark NLP. Here are the links for the other articles. Don’t forget to follow our page and stay tuned!
